awd_titl_txt: OPUS:CRS: Synthesis of decadal changes in controls, trajectories, & tipping points in vegetation cover, spatial structure, & marsh platform elevation in Great Sippewissett Marsh
awd_abstract_narration:
Salt marshes are common features of coastal environments. They provide fundamental services, such as maintaining water quality, stabilizing shorelines, and providing choice habitats for important fisheries. Across the world, salt marshes are under threat from the long-term effects of human activities. These include increased nutrient loading, accelerating sea level rise, and increased temperature and precipitation. These changes may be reaching tipping points beyond which these services may cease. This project uses a 49-year dataset on salt marsh responses to nitrogen addition and other external drivers to increase understanding of salt marsh structure and function. Knowledge about the response of salt marshes to such changes is necessary for better management of these critical ecosystems. Results from this research will lead to substantial contributions to basic questions about ecology of salt marshes and will be useful to stakeholders responsible for wetland management. The full database generated from this research will be made freely available to any future users through DataONE (Data Observation Network for Earth).

The project proposes a synthesis of a rich database derived from long-term research in the Great Sippewissett Marsh, a representative New England salt marshes in Cape Cod, MA. The core database includes a) a high-definition (10x10 cm) record of a mosaic of vegetation, and b) a high-definition (±1-3 mm) spatial distribution of micro-elevations, both measured within replicated experimental 10-m radius plots established 49 years ago. These plots have been subject to chronic treatments, including four different levels of nutrient inputs, comparable to ranges of eutrophication found in the worlds’ estuaries. The enrichments continued while conditions changed substantially: this work therefore will assess how salt marshes exposed to a wide range of eutrophication will respond to interactive and parallel changes in sea level rise, temperatures, and precipitation. Synthesis of this one-of-a-kind database will allow definition of interactive effects of major driving variables, advance understanding of salt marsh responses and decadal trajectories under changing conditions, and develop theoretical understanding of external vs internal controls, stable states, tipping points, and variability of decadal vegetation trajectories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

NSF Award No. 1950058. OPUS:CRS: Synthesis of decadal changes in controls, trajectories, tipping points in vegetation cover, spatial structure, and marsh platform elevation in Great Sippewissett Marsh.  2020-2022, 2023. $413,426.

We received an OPUS grant for 2020-2022, but Covid 19 severely affected our progress, and we were fortunate enough that NSF, aware of the essential need to keep research teams going in spite of the impairment of communication, access to lab and other resources created by medical restrictions, approved an extension aimed mainly to support salaries for younger members of the team. The additional support made it possible to complete work and lead to outcomes that have been received with interest by local and international press, environmental agencies, and stakeholders in various sectors.

Intellectual Merit—Half a century ago, we started work in Great Sippewissett Marsh. We added different doses of fertilizer in experimental plots, to find out whether the increased nutrients that were being reported in coastal waters could be altering the function of salt marshes, widely acknowledged as valuable coastal habitats. We determined that nitrogen was a key factor involved in controlling growth of the arrays of marsh plants, and we were able to map and follow decadal shifts in the vegetation cover annually. Certain species diminished, and others increased as a result of larger nitrogen supply; some species emerged as environmental engineers that changed conditions in the marsh surface. For example, Distichlis spicata (a high marsh species) increased the rate of sediment accretion, elevating the level of the marsh surface. Other species were then able to colonize the raised areas, excluding the environmental engineer species. As we continued the long-term mapping of the plots across the five decades, we became increasingly aware that this marsh (as well as marshes elsewhere) were increasingly subject to changing climate-related drivers: higher air and seawater temperature, and precipitation had minor effects, but the accelerating sea level rise (increasing six-fold between the 1990s and 2020s) forced major changes in salt marsh ecosystems. This altered vegetation composition, extent, and all other parts of the marsh ecosystem by the resulting increased submergence. Using evidence from the experimental plots and data from the entire Great Sippewissett Marsh, plus available data on sea level rise for the region, we developed a model that predicted future trajectories of this marsh, trajectories that anticipated coming changes. By the end of the 21st century, the stark prediction was that, even under conservative assumptions of sea level rise, Great Sippewissett Marsh would be submerged, and converted into a shallow embayment.

Publications include:

Valiela, I, J. Lloret, K. Chenoweth, J. Teal, B. Howes, D. Goehringer.  2023. Salt marsh vegetation change during a half-century of experimental nutrient addition and climate-driven controls in Great Sippewissett Marsh. Sci. Tot. Environ. 867:161546. This paper reviews the five-decade vegetation trajectories in Great Sippewissett Marsh, high-impact effects of ecological engineer species (Distichlis spicata), shifts in key taxa (taller, sparser Spartina alterniflora), complex interactions of changing climate-related drivers (sea level rise had major influence) and experimental nitrogen fertilization on sediment accretion and vegetation structure. It then ventures to assess implications for the future of salt marshes in a changing world.

Valiela, I., Lloret, J., Chenoweth, K. Climate change effects on salt marshes. 2023. Chapter 19 in: Kennish, M., Paerl, H., Crosswell, J. (Eds.). Climate Change and Estuaries. Taylor and Francis Publications. This chapter reviews climate-related effects on salt marshes.

Valiela, Chenoweth, and Lloret. In prep. Salt marsh platform elevation: Constraints on salt marsh vegetation assemblages and interactions with external drivers. This contribution documents how local elevation controls the vegetation mosaic and demonstrates how elevations depend on external sea-level and accretion stimulated by ecosystem engineer taxa. It provides projections under different predictions of the balance between accretion rates and sea-level rise.

Broader Impacts—Outreach to stakeholders and managers: Our concerted outreach effort raised local and international press and management sector attention on threats to salt marsh survival by eutrophication and sea level rise. Outcomes: Our outreach efforts engaged the interest of staff at the Cape Cod Commission and the Waquoit Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve, leading to a series of meetings resulting in collaborative proposals submitted to the National Coastal Resiliency Fund of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation and the Coastal Watersheds Grant Program of the National Estuary Program. We aimed to engage stakeholders and agencies in the application of OPUS results to respond to future threats to salt marsh resilience over the coming decades. This includes defining areas suitable for landward migration and developing strategies to facilitate migration in different Cape Cod locations and sites within WBNERR. We provided examples for coastal New England and other regions. Education: Two junior colleagues (one a minority) advanced their training and credentials through engaging in the OPUS work; three minority interns gained experience by participating in this work.
